There's a much more efficient way, involving practically zero loss of sodium metal, if you can get hold of a bottle of tetraglyme, aka tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether. This is an excellent solvent for sodium oxides and hydroxides, which will comprise most of the surface corrosion on sodium metal, and the effectiveness is increased at higher temperatures. The one catch is that sodium floats in tetraglyme, so you will need to blanket everything with nitrogen or argon to stop the sodium corroding. If you don't have an inert gas source, you could pour a layer of mineral oil on top - this shouldn't mix with the tetraglyme since the polarity of the two liquids are vastly different. Just choose a mineral oil that sodium sinks in. This is similar to the method of cleaning up old potassium with 1,4-dioxane.

Anyway, tetraglyme has a boiling point way above the melting point of sodium - but don't heat it beyond about 150 degrees C, otherwise it actually starts reacting with the liquid sodium. Anywhere between 100 and 130 degrees C should be safe enough. If you put a large magnetic stirrer bar at the bottom of the beaker and turn the stirring rate up as high as it can go, you should form a vortex, and the melted sodium will coalesce in the middle of the vortex into one big rounded lump, with all the impurities dissolved into the tetraglyme layer. Once it has all melted and collected, turn the heat off but keep the stirring going until it has cooled down enough for the sodium to solidify. Then you can pick out the lump with tongs (or a gloved hand if you're feeling brave) and dump it in a clean jar with some fresh mineral oil.

Don't be tempted to store the sodium in tetraglyme to keep it shiny - this will work for a few weeks or maybe a month, but sodium still reacts with tetraglyme at room temperature, just imperceptibly slowly - and the breakdown products form a sticky black tar-like substance. Tetraglyme is expensive, so you may want to recover as much as possible, but this is easy enough if you have a distillation rig and a high vacuum pump. Don't try distilling the tetraglyme at ambient pressure - it will decompose too easily, especially with sodium hydroxide dissolved in it. But at full vacuum (as good as a rotary vane pump can do, anyway), the distillation should occur at a much lower temperature, so less of it will decompose.

Hey Nigel, another great video! Thanks! Watching it, three questions came to mind:
1) Have you ever tried working with sodium in an oxygen free environment like an anaerobic glove box? I know these are usually used for growing anaerobic bacteria, but who says you can't branch out?
2) Can the mineral oil be fully dried either with heat under vacuum, or with 3A molecular sieve zeolite?
3) Have you ever tried using silicone oil (random, whatever weight) to either purify or store sodium?
Thanks again for making these awesome videos and teaching me new stuff all the time! You're bringing back some fond memories of chemistry class with a teacher whose fondness for setting substances on fire closely matched mine! Cheers!

There is a better method tbh..you can use electrorefining. Take a pure sodium and make it cathode and the dirty one the anode..just make sure the dirty sodium conducts electricity. Allow them to sit in water for some time and and add any sodium salt as electrolyte. The sodium cations will go to the cathode and further sodium ions will be released from the dirty sodium anode...there will be an anode mud of the left oxides like bicarbonates, hydroxides, etc and you'll get pure sodium...store it in kerosene oil to prevent oxidation.

Found some sodium or natrium. Dont know what it was. But i played with it for some time.

And i liked cutting it it was so shiney and those colors.

But after some of it got stuck under my nail and started burning. I reacted fast.
Okay WATER and soap.
At the moment my hands touched the water they "exploded".
And it was now clear for me that i was in deep water with this material.

I went back and countinued with the cutting.
Now with gloves.
Short after the piece i had got softer and softer.
I quickly realised that this is a reaction i cant controle. And its escalating.

Now I understand that the original chunks of sodium were filthy with corrosion and whatever else, and that this process certainly removed most of the ugliness, but at the end you allowed it to completely dry of any mineral oil when you cut it, which essentially guaranteed that it would oxidize yet again, and be covered with a new layer of corrosion. Granted it is cleaner than before, but it was certainly not shiny, which, for me, would be the primary purpose of taking the time to clean it. Couldn't it be cut while still wet with, or submerged under mineral oil? I've had about an oz of sodium for at least 8 years now, constantly submerged in the same original oil that it was sold with by United Nuclear, and it's surface oxidation has always looked whitish. It pretty much looks exactly the same as 9 years ago, which led me to believe that it may be nearly impossible for sodium to maintain a clean, shiny surface, even under mineral oil. Maybe that's why you weren't concerned with the light oxidation at the end of your treatment?
Won't adding isopropyl alcohol cause the formation of sodium isopropoxide, which may be the surface impurities you see when you're adding ipa to the oil?

If you place your glass rod across the top of the beaker (so that in looking down from above the beaker the beaker is like the outline of a clock and the glass rod is the hands on a clock showing the time to be 6:00) and then poured out the mineral oil such that it flows down the glass rod, you will find the pouring process to be without the messy dribbling. This is due to the mineral oil clinging to the glass rod until it falls off the end and not over the lip and down the side of the beaker. This is an old trick used by wet chemists for years. It may take a little practice, ut when you perfect the technique it works well.
